basics.name: Kevin Østerkilde
basics.label: Designer & Developer
basics.summary:
Kevin hails from the vikings in the north. He never really cared for institutional education but rather focused on self learning through books and online materials. Prior to getting his eyes opened up for web development, he was interested in 3D technology and it remains a hobby to this day. He’s got unique problem solving skills and can turn coffee into code faster than you can say "Kamelåså"!

One of his biggest weaknesses however is his curious nature and interest in learning new technologies. This on the other hand, leads to far too many unfinished side-projects.

work.summary:
As a freelancer over the past year, I've had the pleasure of working on a few projects, including a VR project backed directly by Oculus. On top of this, I also helped a small startup getting their app ready for launch on iOS and Android.

Clients include:
Applaus ApS, MoonMill Studios ApS, 1937 ApS & Dezimal CPH ApS.
highlights: Working with the latest technologies like React-Native and Redux.
Optimising workflows with both build tools and design systems.
Consulting on UI/UX issues.
Basic shader and material creation to allow for modularity.

work.summary:
At Evendo I was responsible for building completely new native applications for both iOS and Android.

As the sole mobile developer and with an ever evolving set of feature requirements, it was a tough position to be in. The workload never seemed to do anything but increase. However with time, I managed to develop a system that allowed for faster iterations which ultimately lead to completion of the project.
highlights: Close collaboration with the design team to ensure a smooth experience.
Build mobile solutions for our customers, both B2C and B2B.
Managed the entire mobile pipeline from development & testing to deployment.

work.summary:
At LogicLab I was the lead developer of a team of 5, developing an event-based multi-platform application. After a year of development the initial version of the app was launched.

As lead, I was responsible for prioritising tasks, ensuring our developers understood the tasks assigned to them and didn’t get stuck on a problem for too long. Besides managing, I also stood for the majority of the development process itself, as well as designing the visual identity of the brand.

The biggest challenge I faced was definitely taking prototype code and making it production-ready, something which caused many headaches.
highlights: Managed a small team of up to 5 people.
Build and prototyped a feature-rich/interactive cross-platform application.
Developed the brand and visual identity of the platform.

work.summary:
At Quixel I was a part of the community staff team, mainly dealing with live customer support and being responsible for anything regarding VRay integration.

The “live” part of live support was very important, and users were to expect a reply within a short period of time. That was the main goal of our operation. Besides support, I also helped out with my prior knowledge of having used VRay to ensure the exported shaders from our suite of tools were as accurate as possible.
highlights: Fast and responsive customer support.
VRay pipeline improvements and optimisations.
General administrative tasks.

work.summary:
At Billetto I was the sole developer in my team, thus being responsible for the vast majority of the development needs.

My team being growth hacking, it was very organic traffic oriented and because of this I had to build, prototype and A/B test several landing page designs. On top of this I also launched a brand new organiser onboarding experience that would streamline the process of creating an event.

Besides just landing pages, I also overhauled the design of our Zendesk supportcenter to be more in line with the recently updated brand, as well as created smaller widgets such as a pricing module and a quick event creator.
highlights: Build, prototyped and A/B tested multiple landing pages.
Launched a new guided organiser onboarding flow.
Overhauled Zendesk supportcenter visual look.
Helped content creators with optimising their workflows.

work.summary:
At Craneballs I was a part of a core team of artists in charge of developing all the assets for the series of 3D mobile games, Overkill and Gun Master.

My responsibilities was to develop high fidelity, mobile optimised weapon assets to ensure smooth performance on various types of phones, yet be modular enough to allow for the very flexible attachment system to do it’s thing. On top of this, the UV’s of each mesh also had to be planned out properly so as much space as possible could be reused to lower memory consumption.
highlights: Modeling highly detailed, modular meshes.
Sticking to strict poly-counts to ensure steady performance.

courses.title: Build Material Design Apps with React-Native

awards.title: Special Thanks
awards.summary: Credited on the indie horror game, Hektor.

references.name: Richard Palmer
references.reference: Kevin provides quality work every time - he makes changes when asked, with a good understanding of what you want straight away.  Great colleague, highly recommended!

references.name: Andy Pottage
references.reference: Having worked alongside Kev on a handful of projects and prototypes, he's shown initiative and drive to keep the projects moving in the right direction. He always had the project's best interests in mind and his creative flair and knowledge of various technologies means he's always a pleasure to work with.

references.name: Inês D. Soares
references.reference: Kevin is highly skilled and has a great eye for detail. Always delivers excellence work and has a brilliant attitude working under pressure. It has been always a pleasure working with Kevin and I have no reservations in recommending him for future positions.

projects.name: Event discovery app
projects.description: Lively is a mobile app for discovering interesting events in your local area.
highlights: Building a higly interactive experience in Rails.
Presenting a large dataset in an easily approachable way.
Taking an idea from the concept phase all the way through to production.

projects.name: Trainer dashboard front-end
projects.description: A mockup was provided to me as part of a job interview, and I had 12 hours to create a functional prototype based on that, however I've since updated it a bit just for fun.
highlights: Developing a functional front-end prototype under a strict deadline.
Matching the application to the provided mockup.
Adding dynamic filters ontop of the view.
